title: Mass. girl, 11, killed in Utah avalanche while vacationing with family
author: Abby Patkin
bullets: Madelyn Eitas, 11, from Rochester, Massachusetts, died following an avalanche in Utah while on a ski vacation with her family.
The avalanche occurred near Brighton Ski Resort; her brother found her using an app but she later died at the hospital.
Rochester community and schools are offering support and counseling; tributes were made by local soccer programs where Eitas played.

title: Dorchester women injured after snowmobile hits multiple trees in N.H.
author: Samantha Genzer
bullets: Two Dorchester women injured after a snowmobile struck multiple trees near Fish Pond in Columbia, N.H.
The snowmobile operator, a 30-year-old first-timer, lost control exiting a private roadway onto a trail.
The injured women were transported by Colebrook Fire Department to Upper Connecticut Valley Hospital for treatment.

title: Frederick Wiseman, the Bostonian who changed filmmaking forever
author: Kevin Slane
bullets: Frederick Wiseman, acclaimed documentary filmmaker from Boston, passed away at 96, leaving a profound impact on the genre.
Wiseman's films like 'Titicut Follies' and 'Welfare' are noted for their unflinching, slant-free portrayal of societal systems.
His final work, 'City Hall', documented Boston's municipal workings, featuring former Mayor Marty Walsh prominently.

title: Layoffs hit Boston Metal as company plans Woburn shutdown
author: Beth Treffeisen
bullets: Boston Metal to lay off 71 workers and close Woburn facilities starting March 14, citing unforeseen circumstances.
An industrial accident in Brazil led to a critical equipment failure and loss of financing for Boston Metal.
The company, founded in 2013, plans to refocus operations in Brazil and globally due to funding issues.

title: Travelers, did you get stranded due to the blizzard?
author: Kristi Palma
bullets: Nearly 1,000 flights were cancelled at Logan Airport due to the nor'easter blizzard.
Amtrak suspended service between Boston and New York amid the severe weather conditions.
Gov. Maura Healey issued a travel ban for the south coast of Massachusetts during the storm.

title: Boston Legacy FC announces New Kids on the Block halftime show for home opener
author: Annie Jonas
bullets: New Kids on the Block will perform at Boston Legacy FC's inaugural home opener halftime show on March 14 at Gillette Stadium.
The soccer team will face NJ/NY Gotham FC with over 20,000 tickets sold, potentially setting an NWSL attendance record.
The event highlights Boston's sports and music culture, featuring NKOTB's classic hits like 'Hanginâ€™ Tough' and 'Step By Step.'

title: Blizzard leaves Cape Cod buried and struggling to recover
author: Beth Treffeisen
bullets: Over 156,000 customers in Barnstable County, Cape Cod remain without power after a storm dumped up to 37 inches of snow.
Shelters are at capacity as seniors and those needing medical care seek refuge; transport provided by Cape Cod Regional Transit.
Outer Cape Health Services unable to administer medications due to power outages, raising concerns for chronic illness patients.

title: Man killed while clearing snow from vehicle on Mass. Turnpike
author: Samantha Genzer
bullets: Patrick Sarpong, 35, from Vernon, Connecticut, was hit and killed by a tractor-trailer on the Mass. Turnpike.
The incident occurred Monday night on Interstate 90 West at the 104.6-mile marker in Hopkinton.
Westborough Fire and Emergency Medical Services treated Sarpong, but he died at a nearby hospital.

title: Healey lifts travel ban for southeastern counties
author: Ross Cristantiello
bullets: Governor Maura Healey lifted the travel ban for Bristol, Plymouth, Barnstable, and Dukes counties after the blizzard.
More than 250,000 customers in Massachusetts, including Cape Cod, remained without power as of midday Tuesday.
Governor Healey activated 350 National Guard members and requested mutual aid from Vermont for snow removal assistance.

title: ICE scraps plans for N.H. detention center, Ayotte says
author: Ross Cristantiello
bullets: ICE canceled plans to build a detention center in Merrimack, New Hampshire after discussions between Gov. Kelly Ayotte and DHS Secretary Kristi Noem.
Local opposition and protests from officials, residents, and groups like the ACLU contributed to the project's cancellation.
The proposed facility was part of ICE's $38.3 billion initiative to overhaul its detention model across the U.S. by 2026.
